data.title: CLI add project folder options (feature request)
data.body:
Opening several atom windows is still a bit of a performance hit, so I usually try to add project folders onto the existing window using the command palette or menu options.

Having CLI flag (similar to how we have `-n` for a new window) to do that would be pretty useful. It could be `-a` for `--add` or maybe `-e` for `--existing`. It would add the folders to an instance if it exists, and if not just open a new one.

Example usage:

```
atom .
atom ~user/.config/ ../related-project/ -a
```

Result: one window with `.`, `~user/.config/` and `../related-project/` open.

data.title: `open` opens a new instance of atom rather than existing instance
data.body:
This is inconsistent with standard app behaviour.

OS X 10.10.4, Atom 1.0.7

data.title: Batch cursor updates
data.body:
While working on character measurement, I spotted a couple of _cursor rendering computations_ that were not batched yet.

This PR fixes that, so that when a cursor changes (e.g. gets added, removed, or moves) we wait until the next frame to update it. This is consistent with how we handle other updates in the presenter and should as well yield some speedups when many cursors are added/removed/moved at once.

Any feedback is very welcome and much appreciated! :eyes: :bow: 

/cc: @nathansobo @maxbrunsfeld @atom/feedback

data.body:
Hello,

Thanks!

data.title: There is no naming convention of scope selectors
data.body:
I assume Atom follows TextMate [naming conventions](http://manual.macromates.com/en/language_grammars#naming_conventions), but there is no mention about it. It causes misunderstandings([1](https://github.com/atom/language-javascript/issues/47), [2](https://github.com/atom/solarized-dark-syntax/issues/21), [3](https://github.com/atom/language-coffee-script/issues/33) etc.) Also many language packages don't follow it. Syntax theme looks awful for these languages. Syntax-theme developers must create a syntax rule for each language. It's a real headache.
##### I suggest:
- Add docs for grammar naming conventions
- Mention about naming conventions
  - ... in generated `syntax.less`
  - ... in grammar files
- Make sure general languages follow naming conventions:
  - [Javascript](https://github.com/atom/language-javascript/issues/201) atom/language-javascript#206
  - [C#](https://github.com/atom/language-csharp/issues/33) atom/language-csharp#34
  - [Go](https://github.com/atom/language-go/issues/62)
  - ...

Mention in files might be something like this:

``` less
// See list of scopes in "Naming Conventions" section of the
// TextMate Language Grammar Guide:
// http://manual.macromates.com/en/language_grammars#naming_conventions
```

data.title: The "whitespace" package should be migrated as a core feature, and exposed as a preference
data.body:
Rationale:
1. The default behavior is whitespace aggressive.
2. One should expect the user to look into the preferences in order to turn it off, where the user can't find the solution to her problem.
3. One should not expect the user to find the page https://discuss.atom.io/t/why-is-atom-deleting-trailing-whitespace-why-are-there-all-these-changes-in-the-file-diff/19189, because, hey, it's too late, Atom has already lost 10 points of karma.

4.The whitespage package contradicts the "Auto Indent" preference, which makes Atom, by default, schizophrenic.

Related issues: #8425, #8424.

data.title: Atom forgets last window when reopened from commandline or file association
data.body:
This is painful, and it happens to me on both OS X and Windows, on 1.0.7.

Atom is ~okay~ at remembering the window state when closed and reopened from the dock/shortcut. But using the `atom` command on a file or double-clicking a file and launching Atom via LaunchServices/Explorer makes it forget the previous window state, and worse yet Atom replaces the project folders with the folder of the selected file.

data.title: Command-E "Search Selection" is honored by Atom on OSX
data.body:
A very common scenario for text handling on OSX is the following:
- Select some text in App 1 using Command-E.
- Switch to App 2.
- Jump to next occurrence of the text using Command-G.

This scenario is _very_ efficient, fast, and does not require any "panel" or "dialog" or any visible UI. It works with almost all apps on OSX, at least apps that are a good OSX citizen. Command-E, Command-Tab (switch), Command-G, and here is your string.

Atom is not a good citizen in this scenario.

It understands Command-E, but only within its own little environement: it does not inherit search strings from other apps, nor does it shares its own with other applications. It really should.

Atom 1.0.7, MacOS 10.10.5 (14F27).

data.title: Whitespace is taken over by Atom
data.body:
Open a file with carefully crafted indentation. Perform no change whatsoever, and save. Bam! The indentation is destroyed, because Atom thought it knew better how whitespace should be used. And I do not talk about the polluted diff. Related issue: #8424.

Atom 1.0.7, MacOS 10.10.5 (14F27).

Again, I don't know any text editor that forces this very intrusive behavior. Intrusive as in "all your data are belong to us". You could at least provide a preference.

data.title: Saving a file should not automatically append a newline at the end if it is "missing"
data.body:
To reproduce: open a file which has no newline at the end, perform no edition whatsoever, and save. Bam! an unwanted newline is appended at the end.

Where things turn not funny: this unwanted newline can not be removed from Atom, since Atom always adds it on saving...

data.title: At least on mac, Command-W should close a window when it has no tab left open.
data.body:
Today Shift-Command-W is required. Command-W should close the window when it has no tab left, because the intent of the user is obvious. Forcing her to look for the damned command or click the close button is a bad experience.

Thanks for listening!

data.title: Destroy a TextEditor's Gutters when it is destroyed
data.body:
It seems expected for custom `Gutter`s to be destroyed when its `TextEditor` is destroyed.
We decided that the `line-numbers` Gutter could not be deliberately `destroy`-ed, which is why there is a special case for it. 

The change in this PR also prevents an exception that would be thrown if you call `Gutter::destroy` after the TextEditor has been destroyed:
- `TextEditor::destroyed` calls `GutterContainer::destroy`
- ... which used to set the GutterContainer's `@gutters = null`.
- Then if you call `Gutter::destroy`, it calls `GutterContainer::removeGutter`
- ... which attempts to call `@gutters.indexOf`. But `@gutters` would be `null`, not an Array.

data.title: Sporadic X11 error causes Atom to crash
data.body:
I've never exactly been able to nail down the cause of this issue. It has happened multiple times with the same error results. Restarting my desktop environment  (Enlightenment) cures the issue, suggesting the error is perhaps caused by a specific interaction with it. Once Atom crashes once from it (unpredictable) it will then predictably crash the first time a menu is clicked, always dying from the same error code. This 2nd crash will occur even in safe mode, but I have not used safe mode long enough to see if it can trigger the first one. I'm on Arch Linux and using Atom 1.0.7. Below is the last output of a crashed instance of Atom.

```
The program 'atom' received an X Window System error.
This probably reflects a bug in the program.
The error was 'BadWindow (invalid Window parameter)'.
  (Details: serial 3680 error_code 3 request_code 3 minor_code 0)
  (Note to programmers: normally, X errors are reported asynchronously;
   that is, you will receive the error a while after causing it.
   To debug your program, run it with the --sync command line
   option to change this behavior. You can then get a meaningful
   backtrace from your debugger if you break on the gdk_x_error() function.)
```

data.title: Support Babel in all of the same ways as CoffeeScript
data.body:
We want to move toward writing new code in javascript, not coffeescript. For example: https://github.com/atom/line-ending-selector. But before we start bundling packages written in Babel, we need to improve some infrastructure around it.
### Tasks

[The CI script](https://github.com/atom/ci/blob/master/build-package.sh)
- [x] Make sure it runs specs properly for packages that use babel
- [x] Somehow detect when packages are using [Standard Style](http://standardjs.com/) and lint them properly

Bundled Packages
- [x] Make the [build script](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/build/tasks/build-task.coffee) treat babel source files the same as coffee-script files
- [x] Make the Gruntfile compile babel files

Opting in to Babel
- [x] Create an alternative to the `'use babel'` string that fits in better with other babel directives. Maybe this:

``` js
/** use babel */
/** @jsx dom */
```

data.title: All lines in search item - excluding the others
data.body:
New to Atom, looks very good.

As an old man ;-) having used Kedit for centuries, there is one functionality I look for in every editor, the 

ALL /search criteria/

that shows all lines satisfying the search criteria, excluding the others. (Kedit also has a LESS enabling a step wise display removal of lines with a new criteria)

Additional replace, change etc would only work on the displayed subset.

If the functionality is there, I will be very glad (if someone told me), if it could come in a later release - great.

data.title: Icons in small buttons increase button height
data.body:
The style guide shows regular buttons with icons via `<button class='btn btn-primary icon icon-cloud-download inline-block-tight'>Install</button>`:

![screen shot 2015-08-17 at 10 53 00 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/29612/9311917/5989e0e2-44ce-11e5-94a3-33e6f2e00c1e.png)

However, small buttons styled the same way are too tall, making text not vertically aligned, because `.icon` has a static height and font-size of 16px `<button class='btn btn-sm btn-primary icon icon-cloud-download inline-block-tight'>Install</button>`:

![screen shot 2015-08-17 at 10 53 26 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/29612/9311918/5d3580d4-44ce-11e5-8749-8346e0a335aa.png)

Icons should shrink when inside a `.btn-sm`, something like this:

![screen shot 2015-08-17 at 10 56 29 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/29612/9311957/a1313e2c-44ce-11e5-9c77-f16e017ff23a.png)

data.title: Default key bindings not replicated from OS X
data.body:
There are a couple of keybindings missing from OS X which you'd expect to exist within the editor.

For example:

`Ctrl + Left/Right` - Jump to start/end of line
`Ctrl + Shift + Left/Right` - Jump+select to start/end of line

data.title: Bad line snapping (python)
data.body:
Take the following code snippet;
![screen shot 2015-08-17 at 14 44 08](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/651797/9306168/78c52b2c-44ee-11e5-8217-9be85ab74d11.png)

If I now press "Option + Left" to jump back to the previous "word", it jumps to the wrong position in the line, as you can see below. 

![screen shot 2015-08-17 at 14 45 24](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/651797/9306204/aeeeb646-44ee-11e5-8ee2-62d4b6439a2e.png)

It jumped onto the end of the `email_address` string, rather than the closing bracket. My guess is that it not detecting the code context and subsequently doesn't know to jump to the end of the bracket rather than the end of the word.

Instead, it should have jumped here;

![screen shot 2015-08-17 at 14 47 17](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/651797/9306232/dfc2c596-44ee-11e5-82a9-184a9fd83ba2.png)
